articles.headline: Low Rates Good for Banks, but Pity the Saver
articles.snippet: Banks are making money hand over fist in the era of low interest rates. Savers, however, are making next to nothing.
articles.abstract: Banks are making money hand over fist in the era of low interest rates. Savers, however, are making next to nothing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Aren’t low short-term interest rates wonderful?

articles.headline: Genzyme Drug Shortage Leaves Users Feeling Betrayed
articles.snippet: Production problems with two drugs for rare inherited diseases have left patients in pain and may have led to one death.
articles.abstract: Production problems with two drugs for rare inherited diseases have left patients in pain and may have led to one death.
articles.lead_paragraph: Because of a drug factory shutdown, Jeannine Lipez of Lock Haven, Pa., says she can no longer even walk across the street without getting spasms in her left leg and will probably need an operation to replace an artery.

articles.headline: Continental and United Resume Talks to Merge
articles.snippet: United’s discussions with US Airways last week appeared to have lured Continental back to the table.
articles.abstract: United’s discussions with US Airways last week appeared to have lured Continental back to the table.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the music stopped on Thursday in the airline industry’s game of musical chairs, Continental Airlines and United Airlines were back in talks again, and US Airways was still trying to grab a seat.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Obama Widens Medical Rights for Gay Partners
articles.snippet: The new rules are aimed at making it easier for gays and lesbians to make medical decisions for their partners.
articles.abstract: The new rules are aimed at making it easier for gays and lesbians to make medical decisions for their partners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday ordered his health secretary to issue new rules aimed at granting hospital visiting rights to same-sex partners.

articles.headline: Work Force Fueled by Highly Skilled Immigrants
articles.snippet: More immigrants are in white-collar jobs than low-wage work, data shows.
articles.abstract: More immigrants are in white-collar jobs than low-wage work, data shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — After a career as a corporate executive with her name in brass on the office door, Amparo Kollman-Moore, an immigrant from Colombia, likes to drive a Jaguar and shop at Saks. “It was a good life,” she said, “a really good ride.”

articles.headline: China’s Recovery Keeps Focus on Interest Rates and Currency
articles.snippet: China’s economy is surging and resisting inflation, so new reins on the renminbi and increases in interest rates are unlikely now.
articles.abstract: China’s economy is surging and resisting inflation, so new reins on the renminbi and increases in interest rates are unlikely now.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s accelerating economic recovery without signs yet of a surge in inflation may give the government some leeway in making two crucial decisions: raising interest rates and revaluing the Chinese currency.

articles.headline: Debt Worries Shift to Portugal, Spurred by Rising Bond Rates
articles.snippet: Speculators have begun to zero in on Portugal, highlighting the very same economic flaw that brought Greece to the verge of insolvency.
articles.abstract: Speculators have begun to zero in on Portugal, highlighting the very same economic flaw that brought Greece to the verge of insolvency.

articles.headline: Finance Bill Consensus on a Point: No Bailouts
articles.snippet: Beyond the principle of protecting the taxpayer, Republicans and Democrats mostly agree on the approach, but not the details, of financial regulatory reform.
articles.abstract: Beyond the principle of protecting the taxpayer, Republicans and Democrats mostly agree on the approach, but not the details, of financial regulatory reform.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Obama administration and Senate Republicans clash over the future of the nation’s financial regulatory system, there is one principle on which they agree: Taxpayers should never again have to bail out giant financial institutions.

articles.headline: Wall Street’s Win Streak Ends at 6
articles.snippet: Shares on Wall Street fell sharply after Google’s profit failed to impress traders and after the government accused Goldman Sachs of defrauding investors.
articles.abstract: Shares on Wall Street fell sharply after Google’s profit failed to impress traders and after the government accused Goldman Sachs of defrauding investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street seemed headed for another strong weekly finish on Friday — and then the news hit.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Accuses Goldman of Fraud in Housing Deal
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. accused the bank of securities fraud in a deal in which Goldman bet against products it sold.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. accused the bank of securities fraud in a deal in which Goldman bet against products it sold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs, the Wall Street powerhouse, was accused of securities fraud in a civil lawsuit filed Friday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which claims the bank created and sold a mortgage investment that was secretly intended to fail.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson
